Determine the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M=S_1+S_3-(S_2+S_4)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First we have to prove that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I(17;29)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the ellipse center. Suppose "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P(x_0;y_0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be a point on the ellipse "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(E)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". That means:
 "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{(x_0-17)^2}{17}+\frac{(y_0-29)^2}{29}=1729"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{((34-x_0)-17)^2}{17}+\frac{((58-y_0)-29)^2}{29}=1729"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"P'(34-x_0;58-y_0)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is also on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"E"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Futhermore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\overrightarrow{IP}=(x_0-17;y_0-29)=-(17-x_0;29-y_0)=-\overrightarrow{IP'}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the center of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(E)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, as the center is found, we have another diagram of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(E)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/MkqcfgFVnX-post-1788-0-43645000-1321583144.jpg?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose S is the area of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(E)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A+B+C+D+E"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the area of the colored regions. Based on the graph, we have:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_1=\frac{S}{4}+A+C+E"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_2=\frac{S}{4}-A+B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_3=\frac{S}{4}-B-C-D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S_4=\frac{S}{4}-E+D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M=S_1+S_3-S_2-S_4=\frac{S}{4}+A+C+E+\frac{S}{4}-B-C-D-\frac{S}{4}+A-B-\frac{S}{4}+E-D=2A+2E-2B-2D"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A=C+D;E=B+C"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M=4C=4.17.29=\boxed{1972}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1972 is my mom's birthyear and today is her birthday. This problem is dedicated to her."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Bob Kadylo – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Wow that requires a lot of hard work, bravos to you! In mathematics even a small margin can make a big consequence! Luckily this problem is at least somehow extraordinary so you did spot the oddity! May I ask are you a lecturer at the university? "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Leah Smith – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Your method is much better and more accurate. What I did was look at each of the 4 regions separately and then by using numerical integration (Riemann Sums) with 2000 slices - I got approximations for the areas between the equation of the ellipse and the x-axis (4 times). In quadrants #1 and #2, my values are a little bit low because I missed thin slices on the far left and far right where the ellipse went a bit left and right of the x-intercepts. This happened because the centre had been shifted. Luckily the way you asked for the answer, M, made the errors cancel out - the amount I should have added to S1 would have been subtracted off by the amount I should have added to S2. Now you understand my surprise that I got the problem correct. My objective on Brilliant is to learn the more elegant ways of solving problems and use the numerical approximation techniques less and less. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Bob Kadylo – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" You're welcome! It's so normal to resort to calculus when it comes to these kinds of problems I guess. But can you show me how could you do this with calculus? "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Awesome. Actually I did this problem by numerically slicing the four regions and finding values for S1=39347 , S2=30760 , S3=21886 , S4=28501 .... then  61233-59261=1972  !  I knew my whole number approximations would be off by a tiny bit; however, when 1972 popped out I had faith the universe was smiling on me and I should type in that answer ! I like your solution so much better. The strategy is firmly locked into my mathematical tool box. Thank you for posting this problem and giving me an evening of absolute bliss !!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"axy + byz = \sin(\theta)\cos(\theta)(a\sin(\phi) + b\cos(\phi)) ="}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{\sin(2\theta)}{2}*\sqrt{a^{2} + b^{2}}*\left(\dfrac{a}{\sqrt{a^{2} + b^{2}}}\sin(\phi) + \dfrac{b}{\sqrt{a^{2} + b^{2}}}\cos(\phi)\right) ="}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{\sin(2\theta)}{2}*\sqrt{a^{2} + b^{2}}*\sin(\alpha + \phi),"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha = \cos^{-1}\left(\dfrac{a}{\sqrt{a^{2} + b^{2}}}\right)."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This expression achieves a maximum value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{\sqrt{a^{2} + b^{2}}}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" when "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\theta = 45^{\circ}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha = 90^{\circ} - \phi."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In this case "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a = 17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b = 29,"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and thus the desired maximum is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{\sqrt{17^{2} + 29^{2}}}{2} = \boxed{16.808}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to 3 decimal places."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 17 divisors
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the smallest positive integer with exactly 17 positive divisors?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the prime number decomposition of a number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = p_1^{e_1} \cdot p_2^{e_2} \cdots,"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
then every divisor "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d | N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has the form
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d = p_1^{a_1} \cdot p_2^{a_2} \cdots"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 \leq a_i \leq e_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". There are
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta(N) = (e_1+1)\cdot (e_2+1)\cdots "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
ways to choose the exponents "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\delta(N) = 17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since 17 is prime, we can only have one prime "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e_1 + 1 = 17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = p_1^{16}."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
The smallest possible choice for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p_1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is 2, so
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = 2^{16} = \boxed{65\:536}."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Wow, what an amazing puzzle to tease coworkers, and an unexpected insight into the NT! I never looked into the number of divisors before, and the amazing facts pop out immediately: "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
(1) the number of divisors of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d(n)=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" iff "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a prime; generalizing, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
(2) every divisor is a product of 0 to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of every factor of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with the multiplicity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so for the factoring "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=\prod p_i^{k_i}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", every divisor is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\prod p_i^{\{0,...,k_i\}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and, since any combination of the prime factors yields a unique divisor, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d(n)=\prod (k_i+1)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is, curiously, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
(3) odd iff "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a square (all terms in the product are odd iff all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are even, i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a square). "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
(4) Also, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d(n)=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" iff "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a square of a prime (divisors being "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\{1,p,p^2=n\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), and, generalizing, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
(5) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d(n)=k+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k^\mathrm{th}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" power of a prime; even stronger, "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
(6) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d(n)=k+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  iff "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k^\mathrm{th}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" power of a prime and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d(n)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" itself is a prime, so that its computation in (2) is a unique factoring with a single term, which immediately yields a solution."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"More stuff on topic: "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
https://oeis.org/A000005 - a lot of references there. The low OEIS sequence number 5, wow! "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/09/23/the-divisor-bound/ "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
https://terrytao.files.wordpress.com/2009/01/whatsnew.pdf, p. 59: same as above, expanded."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For a little numeric fun, following the Tao's paper, the mean
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M(N) = \frac 1 N \sum_{n=1+s}^{N+s} \frac{\ln n}{d(n)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
(with a small "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"s=10000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to offset the likely irregularities in the range of small "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":") grows, albeit excruciatingly slowly: for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N=\{1,2,5,10,20,50,100\} \times 10^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M(N)=\{1.931, 1.982, 2.049, 2.099, 2.147, 2.210, 2.261\}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The log-log mean,
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M'(N) = \frac 1 N \sum_{n=1+s}^{N+s} \frac{\ln \ln n}{d(n)}, "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
on the other hand, falls as the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" grows: for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N=\{1,3,10,30\} \times 10^6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"M'(N)=\{0.383548, 0.380563, 0.377107, 0.373889 \}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = 2^{a_{1}} \cdot 3^{a_{2}} \cdots p_{n}^{a_{n}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the number of divisors = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\bigg(a_{1} + 1\bigg)\cdot\bigg(a_{2} + 1\bigg)\cdots \cdot\bigg(a_{n} + 1\bigg) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is prime it cannot be factorised as a product of two numbers other than "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \times 17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Thus, to have the smallest possible value, we assign "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"17 = a_{1} + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 = a_{2} + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies a_{1} = 16, a_{2} = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore N = 2^{(16)} \cdot 3^{(0)} = 2^{16} = \boxed{65536}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 17-gon In A Circle
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A circle is drawn and 17 distinct points are chosen on it. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Each pair of these points is connected by a chord (136 line segments in total). "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
The points are chosen in such a way that no more than two chords intersect at the same point. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
These chords divide the interior of the circle into many regions. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many regions are there? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This problem is based on a FB discussion I had with Will Heierman."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We solve the problem generally for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" points. It is obvious that if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", there is only one region. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{ab}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" stand for the chord drawn from point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We build the situation by adding one point at a time. When adding point "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we draw the chords "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{pn}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \leq p < n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". When ever a chord intersects an existing region, it splits that region in two. Thus the number of regions added is the number of intersections between the new chords and the old regions."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose we are drawing chord "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{pn}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Through how many regions does it pass? Each pair of regions is separated by an existing chord. Thus the number of new regions created by chord "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{pn}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is one, plus the number of intersections between "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{pn}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and existing chords "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{ab}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is not difficult to see that chords "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{pn}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and chords "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{ab}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" intersect precisely if
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \leq a < p < b < n."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus the number of regions is"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 for the initial circle,"}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"plus the number of chords "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{pn}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \leq p < n \leq N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":","}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"plus the number of chord intersections "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C_{pn} \times C_{ab}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 \leq a < p < b < n \leq N"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus the total number of regions is
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + \left(\begin{array}{c} N \\ 2 \end{array}\right) + \left(\begin{array}{c} N \\ 4 \end{array}\right)."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Substitute "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = 17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and we find
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 + \left(\begin{array}{c} 17 \\ 2 \end{array}\right) + \left(\begin{array}{c} 17 \\ 4 \end{array}\right) = 1 + 136 + 2380 = \boxed{2517}."}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note: for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N = 1, 2, 3, \dots"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the numbers of regions are
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1, 2, 4, 8, 16, 31, 57, 99, \dots"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
This is the unique fourth-degree polynomial defined by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(n) = 2^{n-1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n = 1, \dots, 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Remarkable!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            What a great question...  At first I was convinced it was just "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{n-1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so when I got to 31, I was sure I had mis-counted...  But, alas, no!  :0)   (+1)

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The Moser's Problem is a classic example of "unproved" induction!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Do you know a "one-idea" approach to establish that the number of regions is equal to  the number of lines + the number of intersections + 1?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I give a solution using Euler's formula. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of vertices  v = number of chord intersections + number of  points on circumference = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\binom{n}{4} + n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The degree of each point on the circle is = (n-1) + 2 = n + 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The degree of each intersection point = 4"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Also note that the number of edges e = "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{degree \times number \: of \: vertices}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore e = \frac{n\times (n+1) + \binom{n}{4}\times 4}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using Euler's Formula : "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"v - e + f = 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denotes the number of faces in the graph(i.e., one more than the number we are after)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore F= f  -1 = 1 - (\binom{n}{4} + n) + (\frac{n\times (n+1) + \binom{n}{4}\times 4}{2}) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" F = \frac{1}{24}(n^4-6n^3 + 23n^2-18n + 24 ) = \binom{n}{4} + \binom{n}{2} + 1 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using this result for the given question with n = 17, it follows that F = 2517."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"[This solution is slightly incomplete. It provides a bijection for counting the number of regions.]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here's the "one-idea" that explains why the number of regions (when maxed out) is equal to " 1 + number of intersections + number of lines (between 2 points)"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Take any configuration. Arrange it so that none of the lines are parallel to the horizontal or vertical, and that none of the points are at the bottom of the circle. For each region, consider the "lowest point". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"orderedList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Show that this lowest point is uniquely determined (thanks to the arrangement).   "}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Show that this lowest point is either an intersection point, the endpoint of a line or the bottom of the circle.   "}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the lowest point is the endpoint of a line, we have to associate it to a corresponding line. We do so in the following manner. Draw a tangent to the point. The tangent has an "upper ray" and a "lower ray". We sweep from the upper ray, through the circle, to the lower ray. Then, for each region whose lowest point is this point, the line that it will be associated to, will be the last line of the region that passes through the sweep. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
A) This line is uniquely determined. In particular, for regions whose perimeter includes the circumference, it will still map to a line. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
B) Each region maps to a unique line and vice versa "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
C) The number of regions whose lowest point is that endpoint, will be equal to the number of points that are vertically above it."}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I was playing around with this problem quite a bit before I finally realized that the number of regions is equal to the number of lines + the number of intersections + 1, or:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_{\text{regions}} = N_{\text{lines}} + N_{\text{intersections}} + 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_{\text{lines}} = \frac{n(n-1)}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_{\text{intersections}} = \frac{n}{4}\sum_{i=1}^{n-3}i(n-2-i)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N_{\text{regions}} = \frac{n(n-1)}{2} + \frac{n}{4}\sum_{i=1}^{n-3}i(n-2-i) + 1 = \frac{17(17-1)}{2} + \frac{17}{4}\sum_{i=1}^{17-3}i(17-2-i) + 1 = \boxed{2517}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 17 gon Probability
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let n ≥ 4 be given, and suppose that the points P1, P2,...,Pn are randomly chosen
on a circle. Consider the convex n-gon whose vertices are these points. What is
the probability that at least one of the vertex angles of this polygon is acute?
Note : solve it for general n and answer for the value n=17
( This problem is taken from a book by sir Andreescu)"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The angle at the vertex Pi is acute if and only if all other points lie on an open semicircle facing Pi. We first deduce from this that if there are any two acute angles at all, they must occur consecutively. Otherwise, the two arcs that these angles subtend
would overlap and cover the whole circle, and the sum of the measures of the two angles would exceed 180◦.
So the polygon has either just one acute angle or two consecutive acute angles. In particular, taken in counterclockwise order, there exists exactly one pair of consecutive
angles the second of which is acute and the first of which is not.
We are left with the computation of the probability that for one of the points Pj , the angle at Pj is not acute, but the following angle is. This can be done using integrals. But there is a clever argument that reduces the geometric probability to a probability with
a finite number of outcomes. The idea is to choose randomly( n − 1 )pairs of antipodal points, and then among these to choose the vertices of the polygon. A polygon with one
vertex at Pj and the other among these points has the desired property exactly when (n−2)vertices lie on the semicircle to the clockwise side of Pj and one vertex on the opposite semicircle. Moreover, the points on the semicircle should include the counterclockwise-most to guarantee that the angle at Pj is not acute. Hence there are (n − 2 )favorable choices of the total 2^(n−1) choices of points from the antipodal pairs. The probability for obtaining a polygon with the desired property is therefore (n − 2)×2^(−n+1).
Integrating over all choices of pairs of antipodal points preserves the ratio. The events  j = 1, 2,...,n are independent, so the probability has to be multiplied by n. The answer
to the problem is therefore
 n×(n − 2)×2^(−n+1.)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"( Solution is taken solely from that book)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
